meanings.definition: Bring under domination or control, especially by conquest.
meanings.sent1: The king was subjugating the neighboring lands to expand his kingdom.
meanings.sent2: The army succeeded in subjugating the enemy forces during the battle.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel was subjugating the bird feeder, claiming all the seeds for itself.
meanings.sent4: The storm was subjugating the coastline, causing massive destruction.
meanings.sent5: The dictator's iron fist was subjugating the citizens, leaving no room for dissent.

meanings.definition: Make someone or something subordinate to.
meanings.sent1: The teacher was subjugating the students' attention by telling an engaging story.
meanings.sent2: The new manager aimed to subjugate all departments under a unified strategy.
meanings.sent3: The cat was subjugating the dog's favorite spot on the couch, asserting dominance.
meanings.sent4: The melody subjugated the listener's emotions, evoking a sense of nostalgia.
meanings.sent5: The villain's plan was subjugating the hero, putting him in a difficult position.

meanings.sent1: The oppressive regime was subjugating its citizens, silencing any form of dissent.
meanings.sent2: The powerful corporation was subjugating smaller businesses in the industry.
meanings.sent3: The loud noise was subjugating the peaceful atmosphere of the library.
meanings.sent4: The darkness subjugated the room, enveloping everything in shadows.
meanings.sent5: The fear of failure was subjugating her dreams, holding her back from taking risks.
